title: When the going gets tough . . .
body_text:
When Emperor Skroob decrees LeBron “King of Jabronis” James to comb the desert, the charlatan complies by scrubbing the Mojave with a limited edition Spaceballs the Movie Hair Pick.
When the Snot Otter goes to work, he uses Yogurt’s flamethrower.
For all the sports news that’s fit to print, this is a one-stop shop. It’s like a bodega, without feral laser cats chasing gutter punks off West 13th Street.
It’s go time.
COYOTES ZOOM TO CIF CROWN
Calabasas High’s girls’ track and field team captured its second CIF-Southern Section championship in three years.
The Coyotes earned the CIF Division 2 crown—securing gold in both the 4×100-meter and 4×400 relays—on May 11 in Moorpark.
Twin sisters Lahela and Zoe Ray, Paige Porter and Arielle McKenzie blazed to first in the 4×400 relay. The Rays, Porter and Marley Scoggins dashed to first place in the 4×100 relay.
In the 400, Zoe Ray took silver while Lahela Ray was fourth. Scoggins was third in the 100 sprint, while freshman Malia Rainey nabbed fourth in the same event. In the 800, McKenzie secured bronze while teammate Arden Keeton took seventh. Calabasas’ 4×400 relay quartet snared second at state in a school record 3 minutes, 42.4 seconds; the 4×100 quartet took fourth at state.
The Coyotes, one of the strongest outfits in Acorn country, won a CIF Division 3 section title in 2022, and finished runner-up for four straight years from 2016 to 2019. Lahela and Zoe Ray are bound for Washington State.
FROM THE (STATE) VAULT
Not one, but two Warriors reached the state meet in the same event.
Westlake pole vaulters Cade Sommers, a senior, and Claudia Turner, a junior, reached the finals in the boys’ and girls’ pole vault, respectively, at the CIF State Track and Field Championships. Sommers and Turner are Marmonte League, Ventura County and CIF-Southern Section champions . . . and history will show that they reached the pinnacle of their craft by qualifying for the state finals in the pole vault in the same year.
Sommers is bound for UCLA on a scholarship.
BUSSIERE BUSTS A MOVE
Zeke Bussiere, an Agoura senior and Acorn All-Star in football, is the CIF-Southern Section Scholar-Athlete of the Year.
Bussiere, a three-sport athlete in football, track and field and wrestling, earned a $1,500 scholarship for being the boy scholar-athlete in the largest section in California. The valedictorian is also president of the Kinesiology and Sports Medicine Academy club.
On the football field, Bussiere is one ferocious dude. The senior strong safety racked up a team-high 116 tackles, three sacks and one bone-crushing hit that was the catalyst to the Chargers’ 21-20 win against Westlake on Aug. 25, 2023. On offense, he had 13 receptions for 90 yards and two touchdowns.
Bussiere and Agoura started last season 6-0, and the Bolts reached the Division 7 playoff quarterfinals.
KAPLAN IS VASSAR COLLEGE ROOKIE OF THE YEAR
Holland Kaplan, a 2023 Calabasas graduate, was named the Vassar College Rookie of the Year.
The outside hitter for the Vassar women’s volleyball team won the Rookie of the Year honors among athletes on all 14 women’s teams at the New York school. On the court, Kaplan led Vassar with 305 kills and 201 digs, and she earned a spot on the Liberty League first team.
Kaplan’s mother, Jordana, wrote to the newspaper that her daughter attended Las Virgenes Unified School District schools Bay Laurel, AC Stelle and Calabasas.
SIGNING DAY EXTRAVAGANZA
The Warriors celebrated a large group of senior athletes for the spring signing day.
These Westlake High standouts plan to play sports at the next level:
• Sydney Bandejas, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, women’s lacrosse
• Jesse Beer, The College of New Jersey, baseball
• Savannah Branham, Ohio Wesleyan University, softball
• Dante Deshautelle, University of Puget Sound, men’s basketball
• Amanda Eames, UC Santa Barbara, women’s track and field
• Mackenzie English, University of Providence (Montana), women’s wrestling
• Annie Finemal, University of Oregon, cheer
• Nicki-Jean Henderson, Cal Lutheran, women’s lacrosse
• Will Kaczynski, Westmont College, baseball
• Ariana Liu, University of Chicago, women’s tennis
• Mia Morera, University of Northern Illinois, softball
• Emma Naftzger, Point Loma University, women’s soccer
• Ife Orekoya, Sacramento State, men’s track and field
• Selim Ozleplebici, Daemen University, men’s soccer
• Alexa Pinon, George Mason University, women’s cross country/track
• Miranda Pinon, George Mason University, women’s cross country/track
• Sienna Schwanauer, University of Colorado Boulder, stunt/cheer
• Cade Sommers, UCLA, men’s track and field
• Megan Sun, MIT, women’s tennis
Mackenzie English is a CIF wrestling champion. Ariana Liu and Megan Sun are CIF state and section tennis champions. Jesse Beer and Will Kaczynski won a CIF SoCal regional baseball title in 2023. Orekoya, an Acorn Newspapers legend who also plays football, is a 2023 CIF champion in the 400-meter run.
In related news, Kayden Elsokary, an Acorn All-Star in boys’ basketball, was honored as the Ventura County Sports Hall of Fame boys’ athlete of the year for Westlake on June 2 in Camarillo.
MOORPARK BASEBALL FALLS IN REGIONAL FINAL
The Musketeers’ hearts broke—again.
Moorpark’s baseball team, which endured a controversial decision in the CIF-Southern Section Division 2 championship last month, lost in the CIF SoCal Regional Division II final 6-5 in eleven innings on June 1 at Liberty of Bakersfield.
Cameron Johnson and AJ Mai belted home runs for the Musketeers in the last game of the season. Mai, Taylor Busch and Greg Lareva notched two hits apiece. Leon Chavez and Michael Leddy recorded hits, and Michael Shannon-Wilkerson scored two runs for the Green Machine.
Carson Cerny did not allow a run in six innings on the mound, and he scattered two hits with three strikeouts and five walks.
Moorpark opened the regional state tournament with a 6-0 win against Bell on May 28 before subduing Ayala 6-3 on May 30 in the semifinals. The Musketeers finished the best season in team history with a 21-12-1 overall record.
ACORN ALL-STARS! FOR BASEBALL!!!
The newspaper will release its first Acorn All-Star baseball team next week.
Head coaches, players and administrators (no parents, sorry) can suggest local players for inclusion on the first all-star baseball team in this newspaper’s history to eliav@theacorn.com until high noon on Tuesday, June 11.
